text.text_translated:
Pornsiri Bunphum 2021 : Diversity of Phomposis spp., Causal Pathogens of Durian, and Their Fungicide Resistance. Master of Science (Plant Pathology),. Major Field: Plant Pathology, Department of Plant Pathology. Thesis Advisor: Associate Professor Somsiri Sangchote, Ph.D. 80 pages. 

Phomopsis leaf spot and durian fruit rot disease caused by Phomopsis spp. It can infect durian starting from seedling to fruit after harvested. This pathogen causes a problem both to the grower and exporter. Disease incidence and disease index of Phomopsis spp. and their response to commonly use fungicides and also other selected fungicides were conducted. Firstly, Phomopsis spp. were isolated from diseased symptom on the leaves and fruits collected from 12 provinces 25 districts and 113 isolates were obtained. They were Identified both by morphological characteristics and molecular technique using MR marker, ITS1,4 and EF1C and their nucleotide sequences were compared with database from Genbank. All isolates were identified as Phomopsis sp., Diaporthe eucalyptorum, D. tectonendophytica, D. litchicola and $D$ Iongicolla with their similarity at 99 98 98 97 and $96 \%$ , respectively. However, isolate. mostly found in many areas was D. eucalyptorum with its similarity at. $98 \%$ , These markers could not make a conclusion to species. Their response to three fungicides commonly used in durian orchards including mancozeb, carbendazim and pyraclostrobin, and other selected three fungicides including propineb, difenoconazole and hexaconazole at 0.5, 1 and 1.5 of recommendation rate were tested. Five fungicides could inhibit growth of this fungus but carbendazim could not completely inhibit all isolates. Carbendazim resistant isolates were shown at $1 8 . 3 4 \%$ $1 4 . 6 8 ~ \%$ and $8 . 2 6 ~ \%$ of 0.5, 1 and 1.5 of recommendation rate respectively. Pyraclostrobin can inhibit all isolates of this fungus and also reduced fruit rot severity by $4 5 . 9 \%$

The distance between each tree and between each row is consistently 8 meters. Method 'ข' shows trees arranged along contour lines on a sloped terrain. Two formulas in Thai are presented for calculating plant disease metrics. The first formula calculates the percentage of disease incidence by dividing the number of diseased plants by the total number of plants and multiplying by 100. The second formula calculates the Disease Index (DI) by taking the sum of the product of the number of plants showing symptoms and their disease severity level, and dividing that by the product of the total number of plants and the maximum symptom level. A single green leaf with some small dark spots is shown below the formulas.

Two formulas in Thai are presented for calculating plant disease metrics. The first formula calculates the percentage of disease incidence by dividing the number of diseased plants by the total number of plants and multiplying by 100. The second formula calculates the Disease Index (DI) by taking the sum of the product of the number of plants showing symptoms and their disease severity level, and dividing that by the product of the total number of plants and the maximum symptom level. A single green leaf with some small dark spots is shown below the formulas.

Next is sample ข, which features a central white mycelium surrounded by a speckled grey area and a dark outer ring. Sample ค shows a colony with grey-green and white concentric rings. In the middle row, sample ง is a light grey, cottony colony covering most of the dish. Sample จ has a dense, light-colored center with sparser growth radiating outwards. Sample ฉ exhibits distinct concentric rings of grey-green and white. The bottom row starts with sample ช, a sparse, light grey colony with a white center. Sample ซ displays a mottled pattern of dense white patches and black speckled areas. Finally, sample ฌ shows a colony with pronounced concentric rings in shades of yellow and olive green.
